channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Marine Le Pen Extols Far Right During Speech in Germany
item.media:description: In Koblenz, Germany, on Saturday, Marine Le Pen, leader of the National Front in France, said that the far right would awake in Europe this year.
item.description: The triumph of anti-Europeans in Britain and Donald J. Trump in the United States has galvanized the Continent’s far-right parties, who are wooing disillusioned voters.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Trump Inspires Cheers, and Alarm, Around the World
item.media:description: The newly formed European Trump Society in Sofia, Bulgaria, watched live coverage of President Trump’s inauguration on Friday.
item.media:credit: Boryana Dimitrova Katsarova for The New York Times
item.description: The president’s inauguration was a cause of worry for many around the world, but some greeted it with wine and celebration.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Leaders Abroad, Joyful or Wary, Face Uncertainty of Trump Era
item.media:description: Protesters set fire to an American flag with a picture of President Trump’s face outside the United States Embassy in Manila on Friday.
item.description: Germany’s vice chancellor said the inaugural speech reflected a “drastic radicalization” of U.S. politics. But some world leaders embraced the new reality.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, STEVEN ERLANGER and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: U.S. Prosecutors Outline Case Against Mexican Drug Lord El Chapo
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera arrived at MacArthur Airport on Long Island on Thursday night.
item.description: A detention memo contends that Joaquín Guzmán Loera transformed the narcotics trade, deploying savagery and the corrupting force of unchecked profits.
item.dc:creator: ALAN FEUER and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: A Colonial-Era Wound Opens in Namibia
item.media:description: Protesters splashed paint on a statue in Swakopmund, Namibia, that commemorates German soldiers who helped crush a rebellion by the Herero and Nama ethnic groups.
item.description: More than a century after the genocide of two African ethnic groups, a city that retains strong German ties is divided over the fate of a war memorial.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Defeated Gambian Leader Ends Standoff and Boards a Flight Into Exile
item.media:description: A ferry bringing back people who fled Gambia because of its political crisis arrived at the port in Banjul on Saturday.
item.description: Yahya Jammeh, who was defeated in an election last month, announced that he would step down, sending a wave of relief through the nation.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Claim Deadly Market Bombing
item.media:description: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the blast Saturday in Parachinar, capital of the Kurram tribal region.
item.description: The blast ended a long lull in militant violence in Parachinar, a Shiite town that has been a center of resistance to the Pakistani Taliban.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Historian’s Latest Book on Mao Turns Acclaim in China to Censure
item.media:description: The Chinese author Yang Jisheng in 2013. Mr. Yang, a noted chronicler of the Mao era, has published “The World Turned Upside Down,” a history of the Cultural Revolution.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Yang Jisheng’s effort to “recover the history” of the Cultural Revolution has become part of the struggle over China’s Communist past, which has widened under President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: South Korea Arrests 2 Presidential Aides Over Blacklist of Artists
item.description: President Park Geun-hye’s culture minister and former chief of staff are accused of blacklisting thousands of artists and writers deemed unfriendly to Ms. Park.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Airstrike Kills More Than 100 Qaeda Fighters in Syria
item.description: A flurry of airstrikes illustrates the challenges President Trump faces in carrying out the vow he made in his inaugural address to combat “radical Islamic terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.S. Removes Libya From List of Zones With Looser Rules for Drone Strikes
item.media:description: Barack Obama and Donald J. Trump at the presidential swearing-in ceremony at the United States Capitol on Friday. It was not clear whether Mr. Trump would keep in place civilian-protection rules established by Mr. Obama in 2013.
item.description: The Obama administration quietly removed a former extremist stronghold from a list of areas where special rules intended to prevent civilian deaths are waived.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What in the World: For a Modest Price, the Streets of Paris Can Be Yours
item.media:description: Some Paris streets still have visible cobblestone paving, but on many the stones have been buried under asphalt and are often torn up during construction. Rather than dump them, the city has started to salvage and sell the stones.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Cobblestones have lined Paris’s streets since the 12th century. When the city began selling used ones, an entrepreneur saw a chance to make unique souvenirs.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Avalanche Death Toll in Italy Reaches 5 as Search of Hotel Rubble Continues
item.media:description: Rescuers at the avalanche-hit Hotel Rigopiano, near the village of Farindola, Italy.
item.description: Rescue workers on Saturday pulled three more bodies from the rubble and snow that covered a hotel in the Apennine Mountains when it was hit by an avalanche caused by an earthquake on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: A Third of Afghans Will Need Aid This Year, U.N. Says
item.description: The world body launched an appeal Saturday for more than half a billion dollars to help civilians feeling the brunt of an intensifying war.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: The Neediest Cases: After Escape From Syria, Another Dangerous Foe: Diabetes
item.media:description: Nisreen al-Najjar’s son Hisham, center, at home in Jordan. Hisham has Type 1 diabetes.
item.media:credit: Nadia Bseiso for The New York Times
item.description: A Neediest Cases beneficiary agency tries to help bridge a health care gap for a young refugee in Jordan, far from home.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

item.title: Budapest Mourns as 16 Die in Fiery Bus Crash on Italian Road
item.description: The Hungarian students had just finished a week of skiing in France when their bus swerved right, then left, then hit a highway barrier and burst into flames. Sixteen people were killed and over two dozen injured in a tragedy that sparked a national day of mourning in Hungary.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Canada Today: Political Donations, a Young Captain and Top Films
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada with supporters in Kingston, Ontario, on Jan. 12. Mr. Trudeau took off on a nationwide tour that included town hall-style events.
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, facing two ethics investigations, skipped the World Economic Forum in favor of a cross-Canada roadshow.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Britain Opens Investigation After Officers Use Stun Gun on Race Relations Worker
item.description: The police, confusing the man with a wanted suspect, had fired a stun gun at the worker after he refused to give his name. The episode was caught on video.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Russia Signs Deal for Syria Bases; Turkey Appears to Accept Assad
item.media:description: Gen. Ali Abdullah Ayoub of the Syrian Army visited Russia’s only aircraft carrier, the Admiral Kuznetsov, off the Syrian coast near Tartus this month.
item.media:credit: Syrian Arab News Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Russia showed its intent to greatly expand its military presence in Syria, and Turkey seemed to soften its opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Death Toll Escalates in Mistaken Bombing of Nigerian Camp
item.media:description: Onlookers waited outside the gates of a hospital in Maiduguri, Nigeria, for people wounded when an air force plane bombed a refugee camp.
item.description: Doctors Without Borders said 90 people had died in the bombing, nearly double the initial toll, and quoted residents as saying that 170 may have perished.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Yahya Jammeh Agrees to Step Down, as 45,000 Flee Amid Gambia Standoff
item.media:description: Gambians at the Escal refugee camp in the border town of Karang, Senegal, on Friday.
item.description: Amid political paralysis in the country, the United Nations has warned of a humanitarian crisis as refugees flood across the border to Senegal.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Amid Fistfights, Turkey’s Parliament Backs a New Constitution
item.media:description: Turkish lawmakers scuffled on Thursday after Aylin Nazliaka, center left, handcuffed herself to a microphone to protest proposed changes to the Constitution.
item.description: The proposal, bitterly disputed by opposition parties, would greatly expand the powers of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan if approved in a referendum.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Godfather of ‘Brexit’ Takes Aim at the British Establishment
item.media:description: Arron Banks at a Leave.EU campaign party in London, on the day Britain voted to leave the European Union. He donated $11 million to the U.K. Independence Party and the unofficial Leave.EU campaign.
item.description: Arron Banks, a born disrupter and friend of Donald Trump, says his real ambition is to obliterate the Conservative Party.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: South Korea Illegally Held Prostitutes Who Catered to G.I.s Decades Ago, Court Says
item.media:description: A woman named Bae, seen in a photograph from 2008, once worked as a prostitute near an American military base in South Korea. Former prostitutes say that few of their fellow citizens knew how involved their government once was in the sex trade.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The International Herald Tribune
item.description: The ruling is a victory for dozens of women who had pressed the government to admit that it helped create camp towns where Koreans worked in bars and brothels.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Punches, Kicks and the ‘Dangling Chair’: Detainee Tells of Torture in China
item.media:description: Xie Yang with his wife, Chen Guiqiu. Mr. Xie, a human rights lawyer who has been detained since July 2015, gave detailed accounts of torture in interviews transcribed by his attorneys.
item.description: A human rights lawyer still in custody and facing a subversion trial describes months of abuse in interview transcripts released by his attorneys.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: ISIS Destroys Part of Roman Amphitheater in Palmyra, Syria
item.media:description: The Roman amphitheater, left, in Palmyra, Syria, in 2016. Satellite pictures on the right show the structure before it was damaged, above, and after.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Once done for ideological reasons, the destruction of heritage sites is now thought to be a matter of revenge as the militant group loses territory.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Italy Cheers as Boy Pulled From Rubble of Avalanche, Along With Others
item.media:description: The scene at the Hotel Rigopiano on Friday. The main building was torn off its foundations by an avalanche.
item.media:credit: Italian Fire and Rescue Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Despair turned to hope on Friday morning when at least 10 people were found alive, at the site of the isolated hotel in the Apennine Mountains that was destroyed by an avalanche.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: A Gathering of the Global Elite, Through a Woman’s Eyes
item.media:description: Iris Bohnet, a behavioral economist from Harvard, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where 80 percent of participants are men.
item.description: Following a behavioral economist from Harvard as she navigates the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where 80 percent of the participants are men.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: Opinion: How Not to Be Afraid
item.description: I had an apocalyptic evangelical upbringing, a father who told me too much about the Holocaust, and a grandfather who was a neo-Nazi and Jew — and I was terrified.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL MARIE STONE

item.title: Opinion: I Went to Aleppo to Study. I Left in a Convoy of Refugees.
item.media:description: A man carrying the body of his child, who was killed in an airstrike on eastern Aleppo, in 2016.
item.description: In the last weeks of the siege, we were desperate for the world to hear and help us.
item.dc:creator: LINA SHAMY
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: South Sudan Cannot Be Allowed to Collapse
item.media:description: Peacekeeping troops patrol at night in the town of Abyei, disputed territory between Sudan and South Sudan, in December.
item.media:credit: Albert Gonzalez Farran/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Current leaders on all sides must be given a graceful exit and guarantees they won’t face criminal prosecution.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW S. NATSIOS
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
